edu.wpi.cetask

Class TaskEngine

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.wpi.cetask.TaskEngine

  • public class TaskEngine
extends Object
    Implementation of an intepreter for ANSI/CEA-2018 Task Model Description standard (see docs/CEA-2018.pdf).

    NB: This implementation does not support multi-threaded access. See edu.wpi.disco.Interaction class for thread-safe methods.

      • TaskEngine

        public TaskEngine(String platform,
          String deviceType)
        Create a new task engine with given default values for platform and deviceType. Note that how platforms and deviceTypes are associated with task classes is outside the scope of the standard, and is not addressed by this implementation.

      • load

        public TaskModel load(String from)
        Load, parse, validate and return task model from specified XML document. Loads the first toplevel element. Validation errors written to error output. Also loads associated properties file(s), if they exist. NB: This implementation does not support forward or circular namespace references using prefixes. Thus task models must be loaded in order such that all external references to task model namespaces refer to already loaded models. Note you can also do stand-alone validation from command line as follows (ignore warnings about schema): java -jar lib/msv-rng.jar java/edu/wpi/cetask/cea-2018.rng models/ABC.xml
        Parameters:
        from - string identifying url, system resource (without leading slash) or file containing XML document
        Returns:
        null if validation errors
        See Also:
        load(Document,Properties)

      • parse

        public Document parse(String from)
        Parse task model from specified XML document. This method only parses, it does not create task model.
        See Also:
        load(String)

      • load

        public TaskModel load(String from,
             String model,
             String properties)
        Load, parse, validate and return task model and associated properties file from strings. Used for DiscoUnity.
        Parameters:
        from - name of model (for error messages)
        model - xml for model
        properties - associated properties file (or null)
        See Also:
        load(String)

      • load

        protected TaskModel load(String from,
             InputStream input)

      • load

        public TaskModel load(Document document,
             Properties properties)
        Load, parse, validate and return task model from specified XML document. Validation errors written to error output. Also loads associated properties information, if non-null. Note that such models should be built using a "task aware" DOM builder. NB: This implementation does not support forward or circular namespace references using prefixes. Thus task models must be loaded in order such that all external references to task model namespaces refer to already loaded models.
        Returns:
        null if validation errors
        See Also:
        load(String)

      • interpret

        protected boolean interpret(Task occurrence,
                Plan contributes,
                boolean continuation)
        Update engine state based on this occurrence.
        Parameters:
        contributes - plan to which occurrence contributes (e.g., matches) or null
        continuation - true iff contributes plan started before this occurrence
        Returns:
        false iff this task is unexplained
        See Also:
        Task.interpret(Plan,boolean)

      • getFocus

        public Plan getFocus()
        Return the current focus in the task tree, or null if no focus.

        Note that this is not the discourse concept of focus (cf. Collagen), but rather a much simpler "execution" focus. For example, there is no focus stack. Also, the focus will not usually not be on a done plan. Management of the focus is the responsibility of the application using the engine (e.g., the Guide), with the exception of addTop(Plan) and removeTop(Plan), as documented.

        Note also that this is not the same as the "next" live action, since in a partially ordered plan, there may be several next actions to choose from. The current focus will usually have the next live actions as its children.
        See Also:
        setFocus(Plan)

      • setFocus

        public boolean setFocus(Plan focus)
        Shift focus to the given plan or null.
        Returns:
        true iff this is an "unexpected focus shift" in the sense of Lesh, Rich & Sidner's UM'01 paper, i.e., we are leaving the current focus when it is started but not done.
        See Also:
        getFocus()

      • pop

        public void pop()
        Set focus to (possibly null) parent of current focus.

      • newFocus

        public Plan newFocus(Plan plan)
        Return first ancestor of given plan which is live or has live descendants, stopping at toplevel plan containing given plan, or null if none.

      • explainBest

        public Plan explainBest(Task task,
               boolean onlyLive)
        Find the plan in current task tree, if any, which best explains given task (i.e., to which given task contributes).
        Returns:
        plan which explains this task or null, if none
        See Also:
        explain(Task,boolean)

      • explain

        public List<Plan> explain(Task task,
                 boolean onlyLive)
        Return list of plans in task tree which explain given task, searching in the following categories, in order:
        1. within current focus
        2. within current toplevel plan
        3. any toplevel plan
        If plans are found in one category, search does not continue to next category.
        Parameters:
        onlyLive - only search live plans

      • ambiguous

        protected void ambiguous(List<?> explanations)

      • isRecognition

        public boolean isRecognition()
        Test whether this engine has plan recognition.

      • getTopClasses

        public List<TaskClass> getTopClasses()
        Returns unmodifiable list of task classes which can serve as root of plan recognition. Typically this is because they do not contribute to any other task classes. However, this can be overridden by @top property in library.
